attributes.title: Affective Muscles on Non-word Emotional Valence

q1.value: Interrelations between Emotion and Speech Physiology Affect Word Valence: Explaining the Gleam-Glum Effect

q2.value: Christine S.P. Yu, Michael K. McBeath, Arthur Glenberg, Chris Blais

q3.value: This is an EMG study that examines the relationship among emotion-related facial muscle activity, word pronunciation, and word affect perception. Previous studies have shown that manipulation of facial muscles alters the affective response to stimuli (e.g., Strack, Martin, & Stepper, 1988). We are specifically interested in the  2 muscles, corrugator supercilii and depressor anguli oris, predominant for expressing negative affect and the 2 muscles, orbicularis oculi and zygomaticus major, predominant for expressing positive affect (Boxtel, 2010). Experiment 1 replicated the Gleam-Glum effect: monosyllabic non-words with the "uhh" vowel sound are perceived as negative (overall emotional valence ratings were significantly lower than the null emotional valence value). In addition, non-words with the “ee” vowel sound are perceived as significantly more positive than non-words with the “uhh” vowel sound (overall ratings were significantly higher for non-words with "ee"). We plan to test the idea that activity of affective facial muscles during pronunciation contributes to affective judgment of words and may provide an explanation for the Gleam-Glum effect and potentially other cases of emotion language iconicity.

q4.value:
The following hypotheses reflect the effect of vowel type on word emotional valence judgment:
Hypothesis 1: Single-syllable non-words with the /i:/ vowel sound are rated as more emotionally positive than non-words with the /^/ vowel sound.

Hypothesis 2: Single-syllable non-words with the /i:/ vowel sound are perceived to have more positive emotional valence compared to the average across all non-word stimuli. In other words, the mean valence rating participants provide to these non-words are significantly higher than the average on a scale of -5 (most negative), -3 (negative), -1 (slightly negative), +1 (slightly positive), +3 (positive), and +5 (most positive).

Hypothesis 3: Single-syllable non-words with the /^/ vowel sound are perceived to have more negative emotional valence compared to the average across all non-word stimuli. In other words, the mean valence rating participants provide to these non-words are significantly lower than the average on a scale of -5 (most negative), -3 (negative), -1 (slightly negative), +1 (slightly positive), +3 (positive), and +5 (most positive).

The following hypotheses pertain to the relationships among vowel type, emotion-related orofacial muscle activity, and word emotion valence ratings:
Hypothesis 4: There is more zygomatic major muscle activity during /i:/ non-word trials then /^/ non-word trials.

Hypothesis 5: There is more depressor anguli oris muscle activity during /^/ non-word trials then /i:/ non-word trials.

Hypothesis 6: Extent of zygomatic major muscle and depressor anguli oris muscle activity predicts word emotional valence ratings.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: In this within-subjects design experiment, participants are naive of the hypothesis being tested.

question.value: This experiment uses a repeated-measures, within-subject (paired) design. Conceptually, this experiment can be understood as having 2 paired conditions (one of the 50 /i:/ words and one of the 50 /^/ words can be matched up by their start and ending consonants). Participants will respond to stimuli from the /i:/ condition and the /^/ condition by rating the stimuli in regards to valence.

q9.value: The 200 word-stimuli (including 100 stimuli relevant to our hypotheses and 100 filler-words), used in this experiment, will be presented in a completely randomized order. This is done by specifying a "randomized" order in Eprime so that the order in which word stimuli appear is completely randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited using the departmental subject pool. Our subjects will mainly consist of young college students. One PSY 101 course credit will be rewarded to each participant. All healthy adults (i.e., no speaking or language impairment and at least 18 years old) who are fluent in English will be included. Participants wearing glasses will be encouraged to switch to contact lenses for participation in the experiment. Participants will spend approximately 60 minutes to complete this experiment. There are no planned follow-up procedures. Before the experiment begins, participants will be asked to fill out a form providing  demographic information including their age, sex, native language, number of languages they speak, whether they have any language disabilities, whether they have any speech disabilities, and whether they have any hearing disabilities. To prepare for the experiment, electrodes will be attached onto the participants’ 4 facial muscles of interest: Corrugator supercilii, depressor anguli oris, orbicularis oculi, and zygomaticus major. During the experiment, participants will be asked to read out-loud (to a microphone) and provide affective ratings to a list of 200 non-words (one word will appear on the computer screen at a time). Out of the 200 non-words, only 100 are related to our hypotheses; The rest are filler words to distract participants from the purpose of this experiment. Participants’ facial muscle electrical activity when they read and rate the non-words will be recorded using the bipolar channels on the SymAmps RT amplifier. Their pronunciations of the non-words are recorded and saved.

q13.value: Data from approximately 100 participants will be collected and analyzed in the study. Data from 50 single-syllable /i:/ non-words and 50 single-syllable /^/ non-words will be collected and analyzed in each experiment run.

q14.value:
This experiment is essentially a replication of experiment 1 (see registration for project "Interrelations in Emotion and Speech Physiology Lead to a Sound Symbolic Case"). Thus, the following power analysis results from experiment 1 will be used to determine the sample size for experiment 2:

1. Sample size regarding participants: According to pilot data involving 63 single-syllable /i:/ non-word stimuli and 87 single-syllable /^/ non-word stimuli, the effect of /i:/ vowel sound on word valence is small (d  = 0.29), and the effect of /^/ vowel-sound on non-word valence is medium (d = 0.62). The result from a power analysis on G*Power indicates that we need to collect data from at least 94 participants to observe the smaller effect on non-word valence produced by pronouncing /i:/ with a two-tailed independent samples t-test (α = .05, 1-β = .8). We plan to collect data from 100 participants to account for unusable data. However, it is important to note that this is likely an overestimation of the number of participants needed because data will be analyzed by non-word stimuli (each non-word produces a data) instead of by participant.
2. Sample size regarding non-word stimuli: 50 pairs of hypotheses-relevant non-words are generated by combining all initial consonants that occur in English one-syllable words with all spell-bodies of interest (either /i:/ or /^/ vowel sound and an end consonant) that occur in English. Initial consonants are excluded if their pronunciation depended on the vowel that followed. Those with a usage frequency lower than 100 (per million words used) in English are also excluded (Kučera & Francis, 1967). Spell-bodies that occurred in only one English word (even if the English word is used with high frequency) and spell-bodies with a usage frequency lower than 100 are excluded (Kučera & Francis, 1967). All pseudo-homophones are excluded. All non-words that were misread during stimuli norming are excluded. All resulting non-words that have meaning due to popular usage (e.g., yuck, yum, yeet,) are excluded. Finally, we include only non-word pairs (single syllable /i:/ and /^/ non-words that match by initial and end consonants, differing only in the vowel sounds contained); we exclude all non-words that could not be paired-up. This resulted in 50 pairs of hypotheses-relevant single-syllable /i:/ and /^/ non-words.

question.value: This experiment involves 1 independent variable manipulated: vowel sound present in monosyllabic non-words (/i:/ vs /^/).

We will measure two dependent variables: the emotional valence ratings of non-words and the activity of two affective facial muscles. For the emotional valence ratings, the participants will rate how positive or negative they perceive a non-word to be using a scale with the following options: -5 (most negative), -3 (negative), -1 (slightly negative), +1 (slightly positive), +3 (positive), and +5 (most positive). For the activity of the four affective facial muscles, muscle electrical activity will be measured on the activities of the depressor anguli oris and the zygomaticus major muscle. Muscle electrical activity for the corrugator supercilii and the orbicularis oculi are measured for exploration purposes--no predictions are made.

For our t-tests, one mean value will be calculated across valence ratings for /i:/ non-words, and one mean value will be calculated for /^/ non-words. For each of the two types of non-words, a mean value will first be calculated for each participant, across all non-words. Then, the average for all participants regarding the type of non-word will be summed and divided by the number of participants to calculate an overall valence rating for the type of non-word. An average across all non-words will be calculated to be used as the neutral comparison.

A. To test the effect of vowel type on word emotional valence judgment:
1 Paired samples t-test will be conducted to test if emotional valence ratings for /i:/ non-words and /^/ non-words, with the same start and ending consonants, are significantly different. 
2 Single sample t-tests will be conducted to see if the mean rated valence for each the /i:/ and /^/ non-words are significantly different from the average across all non-words.
We will also use multi-level modeling to look for item- and subject- effects.

B. To study the relationships among vowel type, emotion orofacial muscle activity, and word emotion valence ratings:

Non-parametric cluster analyses will be conducted to see if there is more zygomatic major muscle activity during /i:/ non-word trials than /^/ non-word trials, and if there is more depressor anguli oris muscle activity during /^/ non-word trials than /i:/ non-word trials.

In addition, we will test the fitness of 2 mixed-effect models. For both mixed-effect models, we will follow suggested standards by Barr et al., (2013) in fitting models with maximum random effects by looking at the following variables as possible moderators of the effects: number of languages spoken by the participant, whether English is the native language spoken by the participant, and the interaction between them.

The first mixed-effect model includes word valence rating as the outcome variable and 3 fixed effects: vowel type (/i:/ vs /^/), the magnitude of zygomatic major muscle activity, and the magnitude of depressor anguli oris muscle activity

The second mixed-effect model includes the magnitude of zygomatic major muscle activity and magnitude of depressor anguli oris muscle activity as 2 outcome variables and a fixed effect of vowel type (/i:/ vs /^/).

q22.value: A participant's complete set of data will be discarded if he or she fails to follow directions (e.g., fail to read aloud correctly more than a few words according to audio recordings of the words).

q23.value: A participant's complete set of data will be discarded if he or she does not provide complete data.

q24.value:
All analyses regarding corrugator supercilii and orbicularis oculi muscle activities are considered exploratory. We may also include exploratory analyses of audio recordings of our participants' pronunciations of the non-words.

We plan to conduct the same analyses using the /u/ and /æ/ filler non-words as those using the /i:/ and /^/ non-word stimuli (i.e.,  to also test for interrelations among vowel sound, emotion-related orofacial muscle activity, and word valence for the single-syllable /u/ and /æ/ non-words).

attributes.title: Physical activity interventions from efficacy to implementation

summary.value:
WORKING TITLE: 
Physical activity interventions in mental healthcare from efficacy to implementation: a bibliometric analysis on the proportions and characteristics of intervention studies. 

INFORMATION: See document attached.
